post_text:
As a new school year approaches, we at BRCS want to wish all of our students and local Logan community a great academic year!

At BRCS, we are committed to providing our local community and students with an outstanding educational and social experience for elementary and middle school students (K-8). We aspire to serve a population that is diverse in learning needs, race/ethnicity, and language background. BRCS provides a positive, dynamic social and educational environment every day.

Have a great school year everyone, we can't wait to see our students on August 22nd!

post_text: One of our BRCS 8th grade students participated in the the Ritchey Science & Engineering Fair at Weber State University last week. Nearly 300 middle school students presented their projects. Our student won 1st place in the category of Microbiology! This student has also been nominated to compete in the 2018 Broadcom MASTERS, and is one of the two selected 2018 observers who will attend the Intel International Science and Engineering Fair from May 13-18 this year. Way to go! We are so proud of you!

post_text:
We think BRCS is a wonderful place to be! We love our staff and our families. We are currently accepting applications for the 2018-19 school year. Forms and other information about our school can be found at www.bearrivercharter.org

Full-Day Kindergarten Applications:
Bear River Charter School is now accepting applications for full-day kindergarten for the upcoming school year. All applications received will be entered into a lottery to fill openings in the kindergarten class. Those applicants not selected will be placed on the waiting list in sequential order as they are drawn in the lottery.

Grade 1-8 Applications:
Applications for grades 1-8 are being accepted now through April 30th. At that time, a lottery will be conducted for admission for each grade for the upcoming school year. Applications received after April 30th will only be considered for enrollment if there are no names left on the current year's lottery list.

post_text: At Bear River Charter, we use Direct Instruction as our foundation. The term "Direct Instruction (DI)" refers to a rigorously developed, research based, highly scripted method of teaching. DI is fast-paced and provides constant interaction between students and the teacher. This method is rich in structure, drilling, and content and excels in educating children for life, giving them skills they need, along with self-esteem and positive feelings about school.
text: At Bear River Charter, we use Direct Instruction as our foundation. The term "Direct Instruction (DI)" refers to a rigorously developed, research based, highly scripted method of teaching. DI is fast-paced and provides constant interaction between students and the teacher. This method is rich in structure, drilling, and content and excels in educating children for life, giving them skills they need, along with self-esteem and positive feelings about school.

post_text:
Did you know?!? Turkey Day trivia!

Benjamin Franklin wanted the turkey to be the national bird, not the eagle.

Americans eat 46 million turkeys each Thanksgiving.

Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin's first meal in space after walking on the moon was foil packets with roasted turkey.

The heaviest turkey on record, according to the Guinness Book of Records, weighs 86 pounds.

Californians consume the most turkey in the U.S. on Thanksgiving Day!

Female turkeys (called hens) do not gobble. Only male turkeys gobble.

The average turkey for Thanksgiving weighs 15 pounds.

Campbell's soup created green bean casserole for an annual cookbook 50 years ago. It now sells $20 million worth of cream of mushroom soup.
text:

Benjamin Franklin wanted the turkey to be the national bird, not the eagle.

Americans eat 46 million turkeys each Thanksgiving.

The heaviest turkey on record, according to the Guinness Book of Records, weighs 86 pounds.

Californians consume the most turkey in the U.S. on Thanksgiving Day!

Female turkeys (called hens) do not gobble. Only male turkeys gobble.

The average turkey for Thanksgiving weighs 15 pounds.

Campbell's soup created green bean casserole for an annual cookbook 50 years ago. It now sells $20 million worth of cream of mushroom soup.

post_text: At Bear River Charter School, our mission includes a commitment to a strong integrated visual art program. To help us accomplish this, we are proud to have The Beverley Taylor Sorenson Arts Learning Program (BTSALP) at our school. This program provides arts-integrated instruction to students, effectively increasing student performance in every subject‚Äîfrom language arts and social studies to math and science. Our amazing art teacher, Brooke Lambert, provides a wide variety of exciting, rigorous, and engaging visual art experiences for students in grades K-8. Check out the video to see the awesome work our students are doing!

To help us accomplish this, we are proud to have The Beverley Taylor Sorenson Arts Learning Program (BTSALP) at our school. This program provides arts-integrated instruction to students, effectively increasing student performance in every subject‚Äîfrom language arts and social studies to math and science. Our amazing art teacher, Brooke Lambert, provides a wide variety of exciting, rigorous, and engaging visual art experiences for students in grades K-8. Check out the video to see the awesome work our students are doing!

post_text:
Jen Pierre - PE Teacher

"Hi, my name is Jen Pierre. My family and I moved here from Maui where I taught elementary P.E. I love P.E. and have a passion for fitness and fun!
I believe that when children are able to exert energy they can experience a greater level of satisfaction in life and learning. I believe all children can enjoy physical fitness when they find an activity they like and do well.
A few of my goals for P.E. this year are to teach fitness, cooperation, good sportsmanship, and compassion.
I look forward to getting to know each of you."

Jen Pierre - PE Teacher

post_text:
Dr. Janet Adams - Executive Director

"I am excited to be part of the Bear River Charter School Community. I am a life-long learner and actively seek opportunities to study and learn more about best practices in teaching and school leadership.

I have served as an educator and administrator for over 20 years. I earned my doctorate in instructional leadership from Utah State University. Locally, I held the position of interim principal of Edith Bowen after having worked as their curriculum and assessment specialist. Before that I spent 12 years in various administrative and teaching positions in the Garfield and Iron County school districts. I also spent 6 years teaching undergraduate and graduate students at Utah State University in the department of teacher education and leadership."

Dr. Janet Adams - Executive Director

post_text:
Cynthia McBride - Administrative Assistant

"I have worked at BRCS for the past 6 years and have enjoyed the family and community of the school. My husband, Matt, and I have four children; our oldest three are girls and the youngest a boy. The two oldest have graduated from BRCS and the two youngest are still attending. I believe I have the best job in the school! I enjoy the students, working with the teachers and staff and seeing my own children throughout the day.

I have spent most my life in Utah. From the age of 8, I was raised in Ogden where I met and married Matt and moved to Cache Valley in 1997. I enjoy traveling and have a stained glass/jewelry business with my friend and BRCS Lunch Chef Jen Kimber.

I am proud to be counted among professionals who are dedicated to children and whose main concern is how to help them stretch their brains, teach them kindness and that everyone belongs."

post_text:
Shellie Thornley - Speech/Language Pathologist

"I received my Bachelor of Science degree in Communicative Disorders and my Master of Science Degree in Speech Language Pathology from Utah State University. I maintain the Certificate of Clinical Competence from the American Speech Language and Hearing Association and have worked as a Speech Language Pathologist in a variety of settings for over 18 years. I have a current State of Utah Professional License and Professional Educator License Level Three.

I have worked in charter schools for the past 6 years and am so happy to be a part of the Bear River Charter School team. I enjoy working with our wonderful students on their speech and language skills and collaborating with our phenomenal teachers!"

post_text:
Clint Nicholes - Resource Specialist

Clint Nicholes is native to the wilds of the Western US, born in Colorado and raised in Wyoming. Clint enjoys the adventures this region has to offer. Anything outside is always a draw and enjoyed to the fullest extent. Athleticism is also one of Clint‚Äôs strong suits; as a college athlete Clint excelled and learned much about hard work and dedication, football morphed into rugby, a passion still enjoyed today along with Olympic weightlifting. He received his college degrees at Black Hills State University in South Dakota in education, a natural choice as another of Clint‚Äôs passions is instilling a love for learning and self-discovery in individuals. Clint taught and coached at Star Valley High School for four years before relocating to Logan to be with his wife and their adventure cats.

post_text:
Kaitlyn Terry - 8th Grade

"I am very excited to be joining the Bear River staff this year. I graduated from Utah State with a degree in English and theater education. I recently taught middle and high school in Nebraska but have since moved back to Cache Valley and I am happy to be back. I truly enjoy working with students to discover and achieve their potential. I believe that every student and staff member has their own set of skills and strengths and that if we work together we can create a truly amazing community together."

Kaitlyn Terry - 8th Grade

I believe that every student and staff member has their own set of skills and strengths and that if we work together we can create a truly amazing community together."

post_text:
Kaitlin Beecher - 7th Grade

"Even when I was young, I knew I wanted to be a teacher. Teaching science has also been one of my dreams and I am loving implementing the state's new science standards. These standards help students better understand scientific reasoning and inquiry, not just remember random facts. I once heard someone say that we are preparing kids today for jobs that do not yet exist. I believe that this true and I can see the potential these students have. An education should empower a child and help him or her make a positive contribution to the world.

In 2013 I graduated from Southern Utah University with my degree in Education with an emphasis in science. I am originally from Southern Utah, spent a bit of time out East in New York City, but I am quickly learning to love Cache valley. I love playing sports, going outside to explore, and playing games with my friends/family."

post_text:
Nate Nestegard - 6th Grade

"I graduated from Utah State University with a B.S. in Elementary Education and an emphasis in mathematics. I am currently working on a level III math endorsement in order to increase my knowledge and skill in math education. I also hope to start a master's degree in math education someday.

I am a big believer in helping students develop a growth mindset, more specifically, helping students understand the process of learning. I'm sure we are all familiar with the phrase, 'I'm just not good at math.' Well I completely disagree with this phrase. I want to change that phrase to, 'Math may be a struggle for me, but the effort I put forth will determine my outcome.'"

Nate Nestegard - 6th Grade

post_text:
Rachel Southwick - 4th Grade

"Teaching has always been a lifelong passion. I remember wanting to be a teacher and playing school even before I started kindergarten; it just called to me. I believe that children can make a huge difference in this world. It is important to teach them knowledge, respect, kindness, and much more, but to me the most important thing you can teach a child is how important they are! If a child feels like they matter, then they help others feel the same.

I received my teaching degree from BYU-Idaho in December of 2010, and hit the ground running from there. I started my first teaching job in January teaching 3rd grade at Hill Field Elementary in Davis School District. I then moved to Blackfoot Community Learning Center in Idaho and taught a 3rd/4th grade classroom. After I met and married my husband in 2012, I moved to Logan, Utah. I have been teaching 4th grade here at Bear River ever since and absolutely love it! "
text:
Rachel Southwick - 4th Grade

"Teaching has always been a lifelong passion. I remember wanting to be a teacher and playing school even before I started kindergarten; it just called to me. I believe that children can make a huge difference in this world. It is important to teach them knowledge, respect, kindness, and much more, but to me the most important thing you can teach a child is how important they are! If a child feels like they matter, then they help others feel the same.

I received my teaching degree from BYU-Idaho in December of 2010, and hit the ground running from there. I started my first teaching job in January teaching 3rd grade at Hill Field Elementary in Davis School District. I then moved to Blackfoot Community Learning Center in Idaho and taught a 3rd/4th grade classroom. After I met and married my husband in 2012, I moved to Logan, Utah. I have been teaching 4th grade here at Bear River ever since and absolutely love it! "

post_text:
Shayleen Dayley - 1st Grade

"I am originally from Idaho. After graduating high school I attended Laramie County Community College, and graduated with my Associate's Degree. After graduating I moved to Logan to attend Utah State University. Here I graduated in Special Education and Elementary Education. I am excited to be teaching 1st grade at Bear River Charter School.

Growing up I always wanted to be a teacher. Not only was it members of my family that inspired me to pursue education, but also the teachers that I had growing up. I still remember those teachers that took the time to get to know me, and wanted me to be successful. This is just one of the things that instilled in me my passion for teaching. I want every student that walks into my classroom to know that they are valued and cared about. I also believe in the incredible potential of each child. One of my roles as a teacher is to see that potential, and be a supporting teacher for them as they grow."
text:
Shayleen Dayley - 1st Grade

"I am originally from Idaho. After graduating high school I attended Laramie County Community College, and graduated with my Associate's Degree. After graduating I moved to Logan to attend Utah State University. Here I graduated in Special Education and Elementary Education. I am excited to be teaching 1st grade at Bear River Charter School.

Growing up I always wanted to be a teacher. Not only was it members of my family that inspired me to pursue education, but also the teachers that I had growing up. I still remember those teachers that took the time to get to know me, and wanted me to be successful. This is just one of the things that instilled in me my passion for teaching. I want every student that walks into my classroom to know that they are valued and cared about. I also believe in the incredible potential of each child. One of my roles as a teacher is to see that potential, and be a supporting teacher for them as they grow."

post_text:
If you have been in the neighborhood lately, hopefully you have noticed that we have had some hard workers helping give our school a little face lift for the new year!

A young scout in our community chose collaborating with Dan Line, school grounds keeper, as his Eagle Scout Project. He organized 15 volunteers who committed over 55 hours of work to cleaning up and beautifying our school grounds and we could not be more grateful for their service!

We sure love our community!!!

We will introduce them to you over the next couple of weeks, starting with Kindergarten and working our way up the grade levels. post_text:
Karissa Morris - Kindergarten Teacher

"Rita Pierson said 'Every child deserves a champion, an adult who will never give up on them, who understands the power of connection, and insists that they become the best that they can possibly be.'

I first heard this in a practicum class while finishing my Bachelor's degree in Early Childhood Education at Utah State University. I believe that EVERY child who believes in themselves can and will 'become the best they can possibly be.'

My hope is that every child I teach feels loved, cared for, and cheered on. They are going to be the leaders, olympians, teachers, doctors, lawyers, governors, etc. of this world someday. My goal is to help each child see that potential and know that someone is cheering for them. That they know the sky is not the limit, that they can do anything they set their minds to."

post_text: Direct Instruction is the foundation of instruction at Bear River Charter School. The term "Direct Instruction (DI)" refers to a rigorously developed, research based, highly scripted method of teaching. DI is fast-paced and provides constant interaction between students and the teacher. This method is rich in structure, drilling, and content. The hard data show that Direct Instruction excels in educating children for life, giving them skills they need, along with self-esteem and positive feelings about school.

The term "Direct Instruction (DI)" refers to a rigorously developed, research based, highly scripted method of teaching. The hard data show that Direct Instruction excels in educating children for life, giving them skills they need, along with self-esteem and positive feelings about school.

post_text:
At Bear River Charter School, we are striving to be proactive and encourage good behavior by teaching behavioral expectations and rewarding students for following them. The purpose of this school-wide approach is to establish a climate in which appropriate behavior is the norm and to promote a positive learning environment for all of our students to enjoy.

Middle School students at BRCS earned a Tri-Wizard Tournament as a reward for positive behavior, and they had a blast! Check out the pics!

National Charter Schools Week Celebrates Education‚Äôs Change Makers!

Week-long celebrations honor the educators, families, leaders, and community members who are opening doors of opportunity through high-quality charter schools. Celebrations come on the heels of the first-ever charter school teacher named National Teacher of the Year and charter school named the Top Public High School in America.
